beginner.title: Net Worth Snapshot
beginner.instructions: List all assets (savings, investments, property) and all debts. Calculate: Assets - Debts = Net Worth. This is your starting point.
beginner.success_criteria: Written net worth statement with all accounts listed

beginner.title: Subscription Audit
beginner.instructions: List every recurring subscription (apps, services, memberships). For each, ask: 'Would I actively buy this today?' Cancel at least 2 that don't pass the test.
beginner.success_criteria: Complete subscription list with at least 2 cancellations

beginner.title: True Cost Calculator
beginner.instructions: Take your hourly rate. For the next purchase you consider, calculate: Price / Hourly Rate = Hours of Life. Is it worth that many hours of your life?
beginner.success_criteria: Calculate life-cost of 3 potential purchases, reconsider at least one

intermediate.title: Automate Your Finances
intermediate.instructions: Set up automatic transfers: Paycheck -> Bills -> Savings -> Investments. Money should flow automatically without decisions. 'Make it invisible.'
intermediate.success_criteria: All regular saving and investing automated

intermediate.title: Salary Negotiation Prep
intermediate.instructions: Research market rates for your role. Document your accomplishments and value. Draft a salary increase request with specific numbers and rationale.
intermediate.success_criteria: Complete negotiation preparation document ready to use

intermediate.title: Calculate Your FI Number
intermediate.instructions: Calculate annual expenses × 25 = FI Number. Then calculate: (FI Number - Current Investments) / Annual Savings = Years to FI. Adjust as needed.
intermediate.success_criteria: FI number calculated with estimated timeline

advanced.title: Tax Optimization Audit
advanced.instructions: Review all tax-advantaged accounts (401k, IRA, HSA, etc.). Are you maximizing? Calculate tax savings from each. Identify one optimization opportunity.
advanced.success_criteria: Complete tax optimization review with one action item

advanced.title: Build a Complete Financial Plan
advanced.instructions: Document: Current state, goals (1/5/10 year), saving/investing strategy, debt payoff plan, insurance needs, estate basics. This is your financial roadmap.
advanced.success_criteria: Written financial plan covering all major areas

advanced.title: Investment Policy Statement
advanced.instructions: Write your investment rules: Asset allocation, rebalancing frequency, what triggers buy/sell, risk tolerance. Having rules prevents emotional decisions.
advanced.success_criteria: Written IPS that will guide all investment decisions

masters.name: Dave Ramsey
key_principles: Live like no one else so later you can live like no one else.
Debt is dumb. Cash is king.
A budget is telling your money where to go instead of wondering where it went.
The paid-off home mortgage has replaced the BMW as the status symbol of choice.
You must gain control over your money or the lack of it will forever control you.
Act your wage.

worked_examples.title: The Debt Snowball in Action
worked_examples.scenario: You have multiple debts and feel overwhelmed: credit cards, car loan, student loans.
step_by_step: List all debts smallest to largest (ignore interest rates for now)
Make minimum payments on everything except the smallest
Attack the smallest debt with every extra dollar - 'gazelle intensity'
When smallest is paid, roll that payment to the next smallest
Repeat until debt-free
Quick wins build momentum - psychology matters more than math
worked_examples.outcome: Debts eliminated one by one, each payoff providing motivation for the next. Typically debt-free in 18-24 months with intensity.

masters.name: Morgan Housel
masters.expertise: Psychology of money, behavioral finance, long-term thinking
key_principles: Wealth is what you don't see. It's the cars not bought, the diamonds not purchased.
Saving is the gap between your ego and your income.
Compounding works best when you give it decades.
Getting money and keeping money are two different skills.
Reasonable is more realistic than rational.
Room for error is the most important part of any financial plan.
daily_practices: Build a margin of safety in all decisions

worked_examples.title: Building Wealth Invisibly
worked_examples.scenario: You got a raise and everyone expects you to upgrade your lifestyle.
worked_examples.framework_applied: Wealth = What You Don't See + Reasonable > Rational
step_by_step: Resist lifestyle inflation: The raise doesn't have to change your spending
Calculate the compound value: $500/month invested at 8% = $750k in 30 years
Make wealth invisible: The cars you don't buy, the upgrades you skip
Stay reasonable: A little lifestyle improvement is fine - don't optimize to the point of misery
Build margin of safety: Save more than you 'need' because life is unpredictable
Remember: People who look rich often aren't. People who are rich often don't look it.
worked_examples.outcome: Decades of consistent below-means living compounds into generational wealth, while those who 'looked' rich stayed on the treadmill.

scripts_templates.title: Lifestyle Inflation Guard
scripts_templates.context: Use when income increases to prevent lifestyle creep
scripts_templates.template:
INCOME INCREASE: $___ / month

BEFORE SPENDING ANYTHING:

Auto-split:
- 50% to investments: $___
- 30% to savings goals: $___
- 20% to lifestyle upgrade: $___

LIFESTYLE UPGRADE RULES:
- Must wait 30 days before spending
- Must genuinely improve quality of life
- Must not create recurring expenses

THE COMPOUND QUESTION:
This $__ invested for 30 years at 8% = $__
Is the purchase worth more than that future amount?
scripts_templates.example_filled:
INCOME INCREASE: $1,000 / month

Auto-split:
- 50% to investments: $500
- 30% to savings goals: $300
- 20% to lifestyle: $200

LIFESTYLE UPGRADE RULES:
- Waited 30 days - still want it? Yes
- Better mattress - genuinely improves life
- One-time purchase, not recurring

THE COMPOUND QUESTION:
$500/month × 30 years @ 8% = $750,000
Is the daily latte worth $750k? No. Investing instead.

masters.name: JL Collins
key_principles: The stock market is the most powerful wealth-building tool ever created.
Spend less than you earn. Invest the surplus. Avoid debt.
F-you money is the most important money you'll ever have.
Nobody can consistently predict what the market will do.
Your savings rate is more important than your investment returns.
VTSAX and chill. Keep it simple.

worked_examples.title: The Simple Path to Wealth
worked_examples.scenario: You're overwhelmed by investment options and analysis paralysis is keeping you from starting.
worked_examples.framework_applied: VTSAX and Chill + Savings Rate Focus
step_by_step: Open a brokerage account (Vanguard, Fidelity, or Schwab)
Choose one total market index fund (VTSAX, FXAIX, or SWTSX)
Set up automatic monthly investment
Ignore all market news and predictions
Focus energy on increasing income and savings rate
Continue for 10-30 years
Congratulations, you beat 80% of professional investors
worked_examples.outcome: Simple, automated investing in index funds historically outperforms most active strategies with far less effort and stress.

worked_examples.title: The Salary Negotiation Win
worked_examples.scenario: You've been at your job for a year and haven't asked for a raise despite good performance.
step_by_step: Research: Find market rate for your role (Glassdoor, Levels.fyi, talking to recruiters)
Document wins: List specific accomplishments with numbers if possible
Calculate ask: 10-20% above current if underpaid, or market rate
Schedule the conversation: Request a meeting specifically about compensation
Use the script: State your case, name your number, then be quiet
Negotiate everything: If salary is capped, ask for bonus, equity, title, PTO
Follow up in writing: Confirm what was agreed
worked_examples.outcome: Even a 10% raise compounds dramatically over a career. One conversation can be worth $100k+ over time.

masters.name: Ray Dalio
masters.expertise: Principles-based investing, macro cycles, risk parity
key_principles: Pain + Reflection = Progress
He who lives by the crystal ball will eat shattered glass.
Diversification is the only free lunch in investing.
The biggest mistake investors make is to believe that what happened in the recent past is likely to persist.
Don't confuse what you wish were true with what is true.
Time is like a river that carries us forward into encounters with reality.
daily_practices: Review decisions to learn from mistakes

worked_examples.title: Building an All-Weather Portfolio
worked_examples.scenario: You want a portfolio that performs reasonably well in any economic environment.
worked_examples.framework_applied: Risk Parity + Diversification across economic scenarios
step_by_step: Identify the four economic environments: rising growth, falling growth, rising inflation, falling inflation
Choose assets that perform well in each: stocks (growth), long bonds (falling growth/inflation), commodities (inflation), cash/TIPS (falling growth)
Allocate based on risk, not dollars: aim for equal risk contribution from each asset class
Rebalance periodically: annually or when allocations drift significantly
Stay the course: the portfolio will lag in strong bull markets but protect in crashes
Think in decades: this is about reducing volatility over long periods
worked_examples.outcome: A portfolio that performs adequately in any environment, reducing the chance of catastrophic losses while still building wealth.

scripts_templates.title: Investment Decision Journal
scripts_templates.context: Document investment decisions to learn from them over time
scripts_templates.template:
DATE: ___
DECISION: ___

RATIONALE:
- What do I believe? ___
- What evidence supports this? ___
- What could make me wrong? ___

PREDICTED OUTCOME:
- If right: ___
- If wrong: ___

ALTERNATIVE CONSIDERED: ___

[REVIEW AFTER 6-12 MONTHS]

ACTUAL OUTCOME: ___
WAS I RIGHT? ___
WHAT DID I LEARN? ___
WHAT WOULD I DO DIFFERENTLY? ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
DATE: Feb 2025
DECISION: Increase international stock allocation from 20% to 30%

RATIONALE:
- Belief: US stocks overvalued relative to international
- Evidence: CAPE ratios, dollar strength
- Wrong if: US tech continues dominant performance

PREDICTED OUTCOME:
- Right: International outperforms US over 5 years
- Wrong: Miss continued US gains

ALTERNATIVE: Stay the course with current allocation

[REVIEW IN FEB 2026]

ACTUAL: International up 12%, US up 8%
WAS I RIGHT? Yes, so far
LEARNED: Valuation matters over longer periods
DIFFERENT: Maybe smaller adjustment (20% to 25%)
